publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in ŠorčuqStadthöhleduring T III Š 72.12

sourceDesc.p: Transcription and references have been transferred from the "Text and Reference Database of the Tocharian A Language" (Gerd Carling Lund University) (funded by the Bank of Sweden Tercentenary Foundation and SCAS).
Transcription and translation are based on .

seg.seg: blood, skin, outer skin, and hair, I will restore, exactly like before. The fourth says: And I will make him living again.
And I will make him living again.
Thereupon, wishing to know their respective skills directly, going close one after the other, they went into another ravine of the Himavant-mountain.
Therein they first saw a lion’s bones fallen apart. (Immediately) one of them spoke [a charm] over water in the palm of his hand,
Darin erblickten sie zerfallene Löwenknochen.
Therein they saw the disintegrated bones of a lion.

(Sofort) besprach der eine in [seiner] Handfläche Wasser [und] spritzte [es] nur auf die Knochen, [und] sogleich die Knochen, || (Im) [Versmaß] Ñikci paṇḍurā ... || [die] weit weit auseinander auf dem Berge in die Felsen gefallen [waren], sogar aus der Tiefe kamen sie hervor - als ob sie flögen [wtl. gleichsam hüpfend], kamen sie zusammen. Die meilenweit (getrennten) fügten sich alle nach Wunsch, [und] voll [und] ganz kam in Knochen bestehend der König der Tiere zustande. Darauf besprach der zweite ... (Wasser) [und] spritzte [es] über die Knochen, [und] sofort fügten sich die Knochen mit Sehnen zusammen.

(Immediately), one spoke a charm [over] water in the palm of [his] hand [and] only sprinkled [it] onto the bones, [and] instantly, the bones, || (in the) [metre] Ñikci paṇḍurā ... || [that had] fallen far, far apart on the mountain into the rocks, even from the depth they came up – as if they were flying [lit. skipping as it were], they came together. The ones (separated) for miles and miles all complied as wished [to], [and] well [and] truly the king of animals materialised, consisting of bones. Thereupon the second spoke a charm ... ([over] water) [and] sprinkled [it] over the bones, [and] immediately the bones [were] joined with sinews.
merely sprinkled it over the bones [and] immediately, the bones, || In the Ñ.-tune: ||
having fallen down scattered far away on the mountain Lokāloka among the rocks, even from the deep they came out, as if flying, they came together,
the ones separated miles [from each other]; according to the wish they all joined [and] fully and completely the king of animals, made of bones, came into being. 1. Thereupon
the second spoke a charm over the water and sprinkled it over the bones [and] immediately the bones were joined with sinews. The third
Der (dri)tte indessen stellte ihm eben die Knochen mit Fleisch, Blut, Fell(?) [und] Haar voll [und] ganz [wieder] her.
The (thi)rd, meanwhile, [re]produced for it the bones with flesh, blood, fur(?) and hair altogether.
then fully remade him the bones with flesh, blood, outer skin, and hair. [And] at that moment it looked as if
At that moment it looked as if it were a motionless Kesara lion, lying asleep. (cf 15)
it were a motionless Kesara lion, lying asleep. || In the Ṣ.-tune: || All four feet
he had folded up and hidden between his sides; lying on the right side, his head placed toward the left paw;
the ears, provided with hair on their tips, he let hang a little, but the mane he directed upwards; only life made him different from a living, sleeping lion 1. || there-
upon the fourth sprinkled water over him with a blowpipe (?): immediately, stretching his paw and yawning, from [his] bed he rose,

Sofort erhob er sich von [seinem] Lager, mit gähnen die Tatze streckend, [und] hungrig [und] durstig erblickte er die Kunstfertigen, die sich in [seiner] Nähe befanden, [und] eben sie alle vier zusammen(?) mit der Pranke zermalmend, tötete er sie alle und fraß sie auf.

Immediately he rose from [his] lair, stretching [his] paw with a yawn, [and] hungrily [and] thirstily he saw the skilful ones, who were close by, [and] crushing those very four all together(?) with [his] paw, he killed them all and ate them up.

p.note: The translation is largely based on 15-16, and .

div.p: Edition10-11. Siegling's personal copy of p. 10 p. 11.

list.item:
The translation is largely based on [[Sieg, Übers. I]]: 15-16, and [[Carling, DThTA]].

a4. The tune has 4x12 syllables, rhythm 5/7.

b3. The tune has 4x14 syllables, rhythm 7/7.

a1 ysār yat_s\ krāṃ yokyo _m_aṃt ne ne_ṣ _t_am nek salu pyutkāsmā_r_aṃ || śtär_t\ t_r_aṅ_k_a_ṣ\ _n_a_ṣ\ śkaṃ wtā_k\ śāmā_n_aṃ [y]· – a2 _r_aṃ || _t_m_a_ṣ\ ce_m\ āla_m\ wcani_s\ amo_k_antu yneś _k_arsnātsi _k_aryatsu_m_a_ṣ\ es lyukrā _s_arki ymāṃ hi – – a3 n_t\ ṣuli_s\ āla_k_añcaṃ lyutanaṃ ye_ṣ\ tmaṃ ce_m\ śiśki_n_a_s\ āyäntu kākloñcä_s\ _p_alkān_t\ – – a4 _s\ āleyaṃ w_r_a nesset yāmtsā_t\ āyäṃtwā pa_p_arss at_s\ _t_m_ak ce_m\ āyäntu || ñikci-paṇḍurā – – a5 – –n_t\ lokalo_k\ ṣulaṃ kāklo_ṣ _k_arwaṃsaṃ : k_upā_r_a_ṣ\ penu _lcär _s_almāṃn oki kaśä_l\ yeñcä\ : kur_s_a –(–) a6 – –(–) _m_aṃtne kulypa_l\ puk tsawa_r\ : pyoc_k_a_s\ puk salu āyäntwāṣi lwāśśi wä_l\ : 1 || _t_m_aṣ wä_t\ – – – b1 – – – sset yāmtsā_t\ ce_s_a_m\ āyäntwā e_ṣ_a_k\ pa_p_ar_s\ _t_m_ak ce_m\ āyäntu puskāsyo kaśa_l _m_alkā –\ – b2 [t] [p]· – – _s_m_a_k\ āyäntu śwāl ysār krāṃ yokyo puk salu papyutkā_t-_aṃ _t_amne _s_a_m\ tām praṣṭaṃ _p_alkāl t[ā] – b3 _m_aṃtne _ṣ_p_anyo kliso sne wāsklune kesār śiśäk tā_ṣ\ || _ṣ_aly_pä\-malkeyaṃ || kākropu pu_k\ ś·· – b4 yu lyäṣknaṃ ywārśkāsi cacp_uku : kliso pāccā_s\ poṣṣāsā to la_p\ śālyiṃ kolyeyacä\ : āk[aṃ] – b5 ktsā_s\ klośäṃ tsru lalku śaśmu śiśri kocä\ : śāmāṃ śiś_k_a_ṣ\ klisontä_ṣ\ śoll at_s\ cami wā_k_am ṣe_ṣ\ : 1 || – b6 _ṣ\ śtär_t\ ku_l_m_aṃtsyo wär camā e_ṣ_a_k\ paṃ_p_ar_s\ _t_m_a_k _s_a_m\ po_t_ak pañwmāṃ śla śewiñlune lakeyä_ṣ\ kā –

a1 blood, skin, outer skin, and hair, I will restore, exactly like before. The fourth says: And I will make him living again. a2 Thereupon, wishing to know their respective skills directly, going close one after the other, they went into another ravine of the Himavant-mountain. a3 Therein they first saw a lion’s bones fallen apart. (Immediately) one of them spoke [a charm] over water in the palm of his hand, a4 merely sprinkled it over the bones [and] immediately, the bones, || In the Ñ.-tune: || a5 having fallen down scattered far away on the mountain Lokāloka among the rocks, even from the deep they came out, as if flying, they came together, a6 the ones separated miles [from each other]; according to the wish they all joined [and] fully and completely the king of animals, made of bones, came into being. 1. Thereupon b1 the second spoke a charm over the water and sprinkled it over the bones [and] immediately the bones were joined with sinews. The third b2 then fully remade him the bones with flesh, blood, outer skin, and hair. [And] at that moment it looked as if b3 it were a motionless Kesara lion, lying asleep. || In the Ṣ.-tune: || All four feet b4 he had folded up and hidden between his sides; lying on the right side, his head placed toward the left paw; b5 the ears, provided with hair on their tips, he let hang a little, but the mane he directed upwards; only life made him different from a living, sleeping lion 1. || there- b6 upon the fourth sprinkled water over him with a blowpipe (?): immediately, stretching his paw and yawning, from [his] bed he rose,

a1 ysār yats krāṃ yokyo mäṃt ne neṣ täm nek salu pyutkāsmāräṃ || śtärt träṅkäṣ näṣ śkaṃ wtāk śāmānäṃ yāmmāräṃ|y(āmmā)|räṃ a2 || tmäṣ cem ālam wcanis amokäntu yneś_(TA)|yneś kärsnātsi käryatsumäṣ es lyukrā särki ymāṃ himavant|hi(mava)|nt a3 ṣulis ālakäñcaṃ lyutanaṃ yeṣ tmaṃ cem śiśkinäs āyäntu kākloñcäs pälkānt (tmäṣ sas|sa)|s a4 āleyaṃ wrä nesset yāmtsāt āyäṃtwā papärss ats tmäk cem āyäntu || ñikci-paṇḍurā(ṅkaṃ) # – a5 – – %2 nt lokalok ; ṣulaṃ kākloṣ , kärwaṃsaṃ : #1a k_upāräṣ penu lcär ; sälmāṃn oki , kaśäl yeñc : #1b kursä(rwā) a6 (wätkoṣ) ; mäṃtne kulypal , puk tsawar : #1c pyockäs puk salu ; āyäntwāṣi , lwāśśi wäl : 1 || #1d tmäṣ wät – – – b1 – (wrä ne)sset yāmtsāt cesäm āyäntwā eṣäk papärs tmäk cem āyäntu puskāsyo kaśal mälkā(nt) trit|(tri)|t b2 p(enu ce)smäk āyäntu śwāl ysār krāṃ yokyo puk salu papyutkāt-äṃ tämne säm tām_(säm)|tām praṣṭaṃ pälkāl tā(k) b3 mäṃtne ṣpänyo kliso sne wāsklune kesār śiśäk tāṣ || ṣälyp-malkeyaṃ || # kākropu puk , ś·· – b4 yu ; lyäṣknaṃ ywārśkā,si cacp_uku : #1a kliso pāccās , poṣṣāsā ; to lap śālyiṃ , kolyeyac : #1b ākaṃ (yo) b5 ktsās , klośäṃ tsru ; lalku śaśmu , śiśri koc : #1c śāmāṃ śiśkäṣ , klisontäṣ ; śoll ats cami , wākäm ṣeṣ : 1 || #1d tmäṣ|(tmä)|ṣ b6 śtärt kulmäṃtsyo wär camā eṣäk paṃpärs tmäk säm potäk pañwmāṃ śla śewiñlune lakeyäṣ kākätkuräṣ|kā(kä|tkuräṣ)

Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]
Lines Translation Pages
a1-2 And I will make him living again. 248
b2-3 At that moment it looked as if it were a motionless Kesara lion, lying asleep. (cf [[Sieg, Übers. I]]: 15) 263


Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a3 Darin erblickten sie zerfallene Löwenknochen. 188
a3-b1 (Sofort) besprach der eine in [seiner] Handfläche Wasser [und] spritzte [es] nur auf die Knochen, [und] sogleich die Knochen, || (Im) [Versmaß] Ñikci paṇḍurā ... || [die] weit weit auseinander auf dem Berge in die Felsen gefallen [waren], sogar aus der Tiefe kamen sie hervor - als ob sie flögen [wtl. gleichsam hüpfend], kamen sie zusammen. Die meilenweit (getrennten) fügten sich alle nach Wunsch, [und] voll [und] ganz kam in Knochen bestehend der König der Tiere zustande. Darauf besprach der zweite ... (Wasser) [und] spritzte [es] über die Knochen, [und] sofort fügten sich die Knochen mit Sehnen zusammen. 228, 466-7, 491-2, 493
b1-2 Der (dri)tte indessen stellte ihm eben die Knochen mit Fleisch, Blut, Fell(?) [und] Haar voll [und] ganz [wieder] her. 495
b6-a2 Sofort erhob er sich von [seinem] Lager, mit gähnen die Tatze streckend, [und] hungrig [und] durstig erblickte er die Kunstfertigen, die sich in [seiner] Nähe befanden, [und] eben sie alle vier zusammen(?) mit der Pranke zermalmend, tötete er sie alle und fraß sie auf. 188


and perhaps change translation to: b4 the hairy-tipped / b5 ears he let hang a little etc. to match original lines? (TI)

the beginning of line a5 is restored to (pkänt pkä)nt lokalok in [[Carling, DThTA]]: 168 (TI)

middle of line a5: [[Carling, DThTA]]: 186 has kupāräṣ for the above kupāräṣ (TI)

a4, b1: [[TochSprR(A)]]: 251 segment wränes set. (BK)

a5: [[TochSprR(A)]]: 251 segment kärwaṃ saṃ. (BK)

div.p:
and perhaps change translation to: b4 the hairy-tipped / b5 ears he let hang a little etc. to match original lines? (TI)

the beginning of line is restored to (pkänt pkä)nt lokalok in <citedRange>168</citedRange></bibl> (TI)</p><p>middle of line <ref type="ms" target="__a5"/>: <bibl><title corresp="ref:carlingetal2009"/><citedRange>186</citedRange></bibl> has <hi>kupāräṣ</hi> for the above <hi>k<hi rend="subscript">u</hi>pāräṣ</hi> (TI)</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__a4, b1"/>: <bibl><title corresp="ref:siegandsiegling1921"/><citedRange>251</citedRange></bibl> segment <hi>wränes set</hi>. (BK)</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__a5:"/><bibl><title corresp="ref:siegandsiegling1921"/><citedRange>251</citedRange></bibl> segment <hi>kärwaṃ saṃ</hi>. (BK)</p></project_comment>
